properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Wednesday night into Thursday. Snow associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to begin overnight or early Thursday and continue into Thursday night. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected with the heaviest amounts falling Thursday during the day. Areas along the north shore of Lake Superior may receive higher total snow amounts due to lake enhancement. There remains some uncertainty with the exact track of this low pressure system and the associated snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required as the event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T08:17:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T16:18:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0707194683.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T06:02:20-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential snow for the BC South Coast Thursday night With the shift into cooler weather, snow is looking likely over the BC South Coast in the coming week. While there may be a few light flurries mixed with rain tonight, the first real opportunity for widespread low elevation snow is shaping up to be Thursday night. A low tracking south along the BC coast will spread moisture across the BC South Coast beginning Thursday evening. With temperatures hovering near the freezing mark, a mix of rain or snow is possible across the region. As is frequently the case, snowfall amounts will vary across the region. Current estimates are that the Fraser Valley, and higher elevations of Metro Vancouver and Vancouver Island have the the potential for snowfall accumulations to exceed 5 cm Thursday night. The snow is expected to change back to rain Friday morning. However, with temperatures remaining below seasonal normals into next week, the chance of more snow remains. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T06:01:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T14:02:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2043631789.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to redevelop today. Lake effect snow squalls from Lake Huron are expected to redevelop later this afternoon. Some of the snow squalls may give snowfall accumulations in excess of 15 centimetres by this evening, especially north of London and closer to Lake Huron. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected today and tonight. Locations: central and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: today and persisting overnight. Remarks: A low pressure system passing south of Nova Scotia will give significant snowfall to central and eastern parts of the Island. Snow will persist today and tonight. Current indications suggest that total snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are possible. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. Higher than normal water levels are expected at high tide this afternoon over the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls today. With the passage of a strong cold front, isolated Lake Effect snow squalls have developed. Some of these snow squalls may give snowfall accumulations in excess of 15 centimetres by this evening. Strong winds gusting up to 60 km/h will combine with bursts of heavy snow to result in blowing snow, particularly over open areas. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Saturday. A low pressure system will impact southern Ontario this weekend. Rain, freezing rain, and snow are all possible with this system. Significant rainfall amounts are expected for areas north of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario. Freezing rain is expected to affect most areas from east of Lake Huron to eastern Ontario. Significant ice accretion or build up is possible. Snow will affect areas east of Georgian Bay with significant snowfall amounts. Travel is expected to be impacted. There is still uncertainty as to which areas will be the most impacted with this system. The Ontario Storm Prediction Centre will be closely monitoring the situation. Warnings may be issued as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T07:53:59-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, blowing snow, and strong winds for Thursday. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm (5 to 10 cm Wednesday night, 5 cm Thursday) Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (tonight), northwesterly 80 km/h (Thursday). Locations: Gander, Terra Nova, and Clarenville. Time span: late this afternoon to Thursday afternoon. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross eastern Newfoundland tonight into Thursday morning. Snow will begin late this afternoon before changing to rain or drizzle near midnight tonight. Rain will change back to snow before morning on Thursday causing conditions to deteriorate throughout the day. Strong northwesterly winds will develop Thursday morning, combining with fresh snow to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Wind warnings have been issued for Bonavista Peninsula and Bonavista North. Blowing snow advisories are possible. Conditions will improve Thursday afternoon as the winds and snow diminish. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T06:25:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T14:26:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3529912615.2020
Area: Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow today. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm by this evening. Location: Queens and Kings Counties. Time span: persisting into this evening then tapering off. Remarks: The storm passing south of Nova Scotia is producing higher snowfall accumulations than previously expected. Accumulations over Nova Scotia have reached 30 cm in some areas and similar amounts can be expected over parts of eastern Prince Edward Island through this afternoon and early evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T03:59:50-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy today. Total snowfall: 20 to 35 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Location: central and eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: today and persisting into tonight. Remarks: A low pressure system passing south of Nova Scotia will continue to give heavy snow today and then taper to flurries this evening over most of mainland Nova Scotia and overnight in Cape Breton. Total snowfall of 20 to 35 cm is expected by Thursday morning, with higher amounts possible over the Cape Breton Highlands. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. Higher than normal water levels are expected at high tide this afternoon or evening along the Cape Breton coastline and the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T06:56:01-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system tracking eastward across southern Saskatchewan will bring snow to a large portion of southern Saskatchewan today. The heaviest amounts are expected over the northwestern and north-central grainbelt where snowfall totals of 10 to 15 cm are possible before tapering off this evening. In addition to the snow, strong easterly winds gusting at times to 70 km/h will create poor visibilities in blowing snow. Winds are expected to diminish this afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T08:25:37-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A trough of low pressure tracking eastward across the prairies will spread snow across southern Manitoba today and tonight. The highest snowfall amounts are expected along and north of the Trans Canada highway and generally south of an east-to-west line through Gimli. Snowfall totals in the area are expected to be in the 10 to 15 cm range. Snow will taper off over western areas overnight and eastern areas Thursday morning. In addition to the snow, strong southeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h will create reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will increase over western Manitoba later this morning and eastern Manitoba later this afternoon, diminishing throughout the region overnight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T08:19:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T16:20:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3507879792.2020
Area: Lake Winnipeg - south basin, Lake Manitoba
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values near -45 are expected to continue into next week. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T08:35:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T16:36:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3584992130.2020
Area: Fond-du-Lac, Stony Rapids and Black Lake, Cree Lake - Key Lake, Wollaston Lake - Collins Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 40 to 60 cm with higher amounts possible over the Cape Breton Highlands. Location: Pictou, Antigonish, Inverness, and Victoria Counties. Time span: heaviest today, with moderate snow tonight tapering off on Thursday Remarks: Heavy snow will continue today and persist as moderate snow this evening and overnight. Snow will slowly taper off through the day on Thursday, however isolated snow squalls are possible tonight and Thursday as colder air moves into the region. Total amounts could exceed 60 cm in areas of heaviest snow. In addition, strong northerly winds will develop this afternoon which, given the fresh fluffy snow, will produce widespread reduce visibility in blowing snow beginning late this afternoon and continuing tonight and Thursday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T08:54:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T16:55:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1951420124.2020
Area: Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h becoming northwesterly near 70 km/h overnight tonight. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Location: Inland over the Burgeo highway. Time span: tonight and Thursday morning. Remarks: Fresh snow and moderate winds will combine to cause poor visibility in blowing snow, especially inland along the Burgeo highway. Conditions along the coast should be less severe. Conditions will begin to improve Thursday morning as the snow tapers off. Northwesterly gusts to 70 km/h will persist until Thursday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T10:59:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T19:15:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2456717231.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system is gradually moving out of the Columbia regions. The snow has ended for the North Columbia and Kinbasket. About 25 cm centimetres fell in Blue River from this storm. Radar shows that snow will continue for a couple of more hours over the West Columbia this morning. 30 to 40 cm of snow fell in Revelstoke and another couple of cm's is likely before the snow ends later this morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T20:33:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T15:37:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3210111795.2020
Area: West Columbia
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum gusts: Southwesterly between 100 and 130 km/h. Locations: southern half of the Burin Peninsula, most of the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: midnight tonight to Thursday morning. Remarks: After the southwesterlies diminish Thursday morning, winds will shift to northwesterly. Over the northern Avalon Peninsula winds will likely gust near 80 km/h Thursday afternoon. Additionally, large waves and pounding surf are expected in Placentia and St. Mary's Bays overnight tonight. Water levels may be higher than normal during that time giving the potential for minor coastal flooding, especially near high tide. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may cause downed trees or toss loose objects. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:13:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T19:14:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1479959283.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T06:02:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T16:47:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3852270253.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow expected tonight and Thursday. Total Snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: Generally northwesterly near 80 km/h. Northwesterly gusts near 100 km/h are expected in the Port aux Basques area overnight Wednesday night. Gusts near 120 km/h will develop along the northeast coast on Thursday morning. Locations: Port aux Basques to Gros Morne, Central and Northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: tonight through Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will combine with strong winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow tonight and Thursday. Conditions will gradually improve late Thursday as winds and snow diminish. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:14:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T19:15:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0950383406.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy today. Total snowfall: near 15 cm except near 30 over the higher terrain in Cumberland and Colchester Counties. Maximum wind gusts: near 50 km/h. Location: Kings and Cumberland Counties and Colchester County - Cobequid Bay. Time span: continuing this afternoon and tapering off this evening. Remarks: A low pressure system passing south of Nova Scotia today is bringing slightly more snow that was previously expected. Total snowfall amounts in these areas is now expected to reach 15 cm by mid evening tonight, with near 30 cm expected over higher terrain, such as the Cobequid Pass. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-09T04:59:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-08T17:23:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3838899825.2020
Area: Kings County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls possible today. Strong northwesterly winds will result in the development of isolated snow squalls near Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. At this point in time, the snow squalls are expected to remain south and east of the area. However, if winds shift slightly, a snow squall warning may be required. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: northwesterly near 120 km/h. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula and Bonavista North. Time span: Thursday morning until Thursday evening. Remarks: Strong easterly winds gusting between 70 and 80 km/h will develop this evening. Winds will briefly diminish overnight before quickly reintensifying Thursday morning from the northwest. These northwest winds will combine with falling snow to give reduced visibility at times, especially in Bonavista North. Winds will gradually diminish Thursday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-09T11:17:12-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values near -50 have developed in portions of the northern Mackenzie Valley and South Delta regions. Extreme cold conditions will end later today for the south Delta region and will likely need to be expanded southwards into the northern Great Slave area tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
